@shliang0603 You can compare lbfs's fork with the original repo: https://github.com/iperov/DeepFaceLab/compare/master...lbfs:master
In this particular case look up what was changed in nnlib/device.py

I've been trying to find a proper fix for this, because the current fix feels like a hack. 
Right now, in order to get this error to go away you need to recall nvmlInit() either in functions themselves or the method I've implemented where it is called in Config() 

For whatever reason, even though the original nvmlInit() works in the bottom of the device.py and the device functions right after work, once we return to DeviceConfig everything falls apart and breaks until nvmlInit() is called again. 

Heres the small fix I implemented to make something work
https://github.com/lbfs/DeepFaceLab_Linux/commit/80c3d53650c858fe08a15adebecb41d536e7f566

I'd really like to figure out a proper fix, but attempting to debug this in Visual Studio Code, it actually works there momentarily, but then the entire program hangs in an infinite loop.

> original nvmlInit() works in the bottom of the device.py 

you are wrong. 
nvmlInit() called on device.py import before any `devicelib.function` call
also subj code is outdated

Yeah I understand that nvmlInit() is called before any of the devicelib.function calls. 

https://github.com/lbfs/DeepFaceLab_Linux/commit/c9af42c43622ba3a76d5ff87592f90c1e5cea99e

The issue being experienced seems odd, considering this works on Windows without much problem. I've attached a better fix I'm using in my repository now, but I still don't think it's the best fix to be using. I'll have to look more into it when I have time. At least it allows all the extractors to be usable for the end users.

may be this is a python problem?
python should to run device.py code on subprocess start
I mean possibly, I don't know what the difference would be. The code does seem to be ran on import, just the places it can be accessed seemed to be reduced compared to Windows.
write print()s in device.py around initialization and check

In device.py
```python
if device.backend is None and not force_tf_cpu:
    #first trying to load NVSMI and detect CUDA devices for tensorflow backend,
    #even force_plaidML is choosed, because if plaidML will fail, we can choose tensorflow
    try:
        nvmlInit()
        has_nvml = True
        device.backend = "tensorflow"   #set tensorflow backend in order to use device.*device() functions
        
        gpu_idxs = device.getAllDevicesIdxsList()
        gpu_caps = np.array ( [ device.getDeviceComputeCapability(gpu_idx) for gpu_idx in gpu_idxs ] )
        
        print(gpu_idxs)
        print(gpu_caps)
        print([ (i, nvmlDeviceGetName(nvmlDeviceGetHandleByIndex(i)).decode() ) for i in device.getValidDeviceIdxsEnumerator() ])
```

O_O
this is not minimal.
I mean in one file.
I'll try going a bit further than. Ooops.
dont use files from DFL at all.

```python
import traceback
from multiprocessing import Process

from pynvml import *
   
try:
    nvmlInit()
    print("Initalized correctly globally")
except:
    print("Failure to initalize globally")

def run_test():
    #Failure Case
    try:
        print("\nFailure case")
        print("Did not fail: ", nvmlDeviceGetCount())
    except:
        print(traceback.format_exc())

    #Now Fix It
    print("Forcing NVML Initialization (Only required on Linux!)")
    nvmlInit()
    print("Device Count", nvmlDeviceGetCount())

p = Process(target=run_test, args=() )
p.start()
p.join()


```
I was unable to figure out a way to replicate the issue without relying on pynvml, but this is the most minimal code I've gotten so far
